Struggling Kansas City
When the Kansas City Wizards rebranded as Sporting Kansas City ahead of 2011, it ended up coinciding with a change in the clubâ€™s fate. After years of floundering results and making the playoffs just twice in the previous six seasons, Kansas City became one of MLSâ€™ model clubs. Over the next eight seasons, Sporting never missed the postseason. From 2011 to 2018, they topped their conference regular season title three times, won the U.S. Open Cup on three occasions, and beat Real Salt Lake in the now-classic 2013 MLS Cup. They did it with a clear identity under head coach Peter Vermes, a core of dependable veteran mainstays and a growing influx of homegrown talent.
By comparison, the teamâ€™s last 42 games have felt more Wizardly woeful than Sporting strong. Saturday brought the latest frustration, a 3-0 defeat against a resurgent San Jose side that sits fifth in the West. Since the start of 2022, Sporting has earned just 43 points, with a goal differential of -21. After finishing 23rd among MLSâ€™s 28 teams last year, the club is currently the leagueâ€™s second-worst side, only topping CF MontrÃ©al (who have a game in hand) on goal differential. When tracking their rolling expected goals difference, it isnâ€™t as if Sporting has looked bad over the relatively more turbulent past five years. Expected goals help measure the number and quality of chances that a team both generates and concedes. A positive xG differential suggests a team that creates more and/or better scoring chances than their opponents, using historical data to assess each shot based on its assist type, shot angle and distance from goal, whether it was kicked or headed, and other criteria.
From the start of 2019 to the midpoint of 2021, Kansas City was seldom outplayed according to the underlying numbers. Over the past 20-odd months, however, theyâ€™ve struggled to keep pace with the opposition.

The coach took just three questions before joining his side on the solemn trek home. The first asked for his thoughts on how the team fared before a 38th minute red card to center back Robert Castellanos on a challenge in the box (â€œI thought we were pretty good actually. I am not even sure itâ€™s a penalty. Red card? No chance.â€). The second focused on what came next: a penalty kick to extend the deficit to 2-0 and playing a full second half down a man (â€œAgain when youâ€™re playing a man down, itâ€™s never an easy situation especially when they went up 2-0 at that point. The clincher, however, asked how his team could turn things around as the season nears its second quarter. Without penalty kick decisions to assess in this context, Vermes backed his players to stop the rot.
â€œI think the guys had a good mindset going into the game,â€ Vermes said. â€œI really do. Obviously, when youâ€™re in a situation, you doubt yourself a little bit. I thought the mindset was actually really good. Right now, some things just arenâ€™t going our way. Weâ€™re in the game. We have got to try to keep that mentality. You can turn things around, and I believe that these guys can.â€
Last season, the underwhelming results were somewhat predictable. Kansas City lost record-signing striker Alan Pulido to a knee injury in January, while fellow designated player Gadi Kinda was also shut down for the season before playing a single minute with a knee injury. Seemingly, then, having both key attackers return in 2023 should have been a reason for optimism. Of course, season-ending injuries are seldom a cinch to recover from; Pulido has yet to score in 132 minutes of play, while Kinda has yet to make his season debut. The third designated player, 33-year-old Johnny Russell, has also failed to score a goal or contribute an assist in 250 minutes.
As a team that rosters three true designated players (neither qualifying as U-22 initiative signings, nor as DPs who can be bought down by TAM), Sporting could hope to have its DPs play a maximum of 27.27% of their minutes or 270 of a possible 990 minutes per match. The club has had increased output from its homegrown players as well, most prominently former midfielder Gianluca Busio, attacker DÃ¡niel SallÃ³i and goalkeeper John Pulskamp. As such, a team would hope that the rise in homegrown minutes would allow them to prioritize spreading more of the salary budget across the upper end of the roster as the squad numbers are more thriftily filledâ€¦
Instead, the rise in homegrown productivity has not been met by sustained involvement from the teamâ€™s highest earners. Since the 2018 season, their designated players have contributed fewer minutes year-over-year; non-DPs and non-homegrowns have had their minute share go from 69.7% in 2021 (when the club finished 3rd in the West) to 77% in the young season to date.
At its best, Vermesâ€™ team was lauded for a few hallmark traits. Alongside the balanced approach to roster building and consistency in tactics and personnel compared to many MLS peers, Sporting was a difficult team to break down. Before counter-pressing was all the rage following the rise of JÃ¼rgen Klopp, Vermes was proactive in having players lead the defensive press from the front. Over the last half-decade, however, his team has allowed more passes before making a defensive action with each passing season.
In short, the team is simultaneously allowing its opponents both a higher comparative sum of chances taken and a less stingy press to work through in build-up. Beyond getting more from their three designated players, the path back to contention is hard to chart aside from simply saying the team needs to play better. After U.S. Soccer contacted Vermes regarding their vacant sporting director position, he instead signed an extension with Sporting through the 2028 season. It complicates the potential to turn the page, as the Earthquakes have by bringing in Luchi Gonzalez to change how the club is perceived with its now-burgeoning youth pipeline.
